"**The Farm** " is the seventeenth episode of the [ninth
season](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._season_9\) "The Office \(U.S. season 9\)") of
the American [comedy](/wiki/Comedy "Comedy") [television
series](/wiki/Television_series "Television series") _[The
Office](/wiki/The_Office_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Office \(U.S. TV series\)")_
and the 192nd overall. It originally aired on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") on March
14, 2013. The episode guest stars [Matt Jones](/wiki/Matt_L._Jones "Matt L.
Jones") as Dwight's cousin Zeke, [Majandra Delfino](/wiki/Majandra_Delfino
"Majandra Delfino") as Dwight's sister Fannie, Blake Garrett Rosenthal as his
nephew, and [Thomas Middleditch](/wiki/Thomas_Middleditch "Thomas
Middleditch") as his brother.

The series—[presented as if it were a real documentary](/wiki/Mockumentary
"Mockumentary")—depicts the everyday lives of office employees in the
[Scranton, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania "Scranton,
Pennsylvania"), branch of the fictional [Dunder Mifflin](/wiki/Dunder_Mifflin
"Dunder Mifflin") Paper Company. The episode revolves around [Dwight
Schrute](/wiki/Dwight_Schrute "Dwight Schrute") ([Rainn
Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson")) and [Oscar
Martinez](/wiki/Oscar_Martinez_\(The_Office\) "Oscar Martinez \(The Office\)")
([Oscar Nunez](/wiki/Oscar_Nunez "Oscar Nunez")) who attend the funeral of
Dwight's Aunt Shirley at Schrute Farms. Dwight receives his aunt's property,
and he and his siblings decide to run it. Meanwhile, [Todd
Packer](/wiki/Todd_Packer "Todd Packer") ([David
Koechner](/wiki/David_Koechner "David Koechner")) returns to the office to get
back at them for his firing a year prior.

"The Farm" was produced to serve as a [backdoor
pilot](/wiki/Television_pilot#Backdoor_pilot "Television pilot") for a
proposed spin-off series starring Wilson as Dwight, which NBC ultimately did
not pick up. The episode received mostly negative reviews from television
critics, with many criticizing Dwight's farm storyline and some critics
calling it a "Frankenstein episode". The episode was viewed by 3.54 million
viewers and received a 1.9/5 rating among adults between the ages of 18 and
49. The episode ranked fourth in its timeslot, and it was the highest-rated
NBC series of the night.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Farm_\(The_Office\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

[Dwight Schrute](/wiki/Dwight_Schrute "Dwight Schrute") ([Rainn
Wilson](/wiki/Rainn_Wilson "Rainn Wilson")) receives news that his Aunt
Shirley has died, and he informs the office. The only co-worker he invites to
the funeral is [Oscar Martinez](/wiki/Oscar_Martinez_\(The_Office\) "Oscar
Martinez \(The Office\)") ([Oscar Nunez](/wiki/Oscar_Nunez "Oscar Nunez")),
who flees when Dwight begins shooting the corpse with a shotgun to ensure it
is really dead. At the funeral, Dwight's family gathers: his cousins Mose
([Michael Schur](/wiki/Michael_Schur "Michael Schur")) and Zeke ([Matt
Jones](/wiki/Matt_L._Jones "Matt L. Jones")), his brother Jeb ([Thomas
Middleditch](/wiki/Thomas_Middleditch "Thomas Middleditch")), his sister
Fannie ([Majandra Delfino](/wiki/Majandra_Delfino "Majandra Delfino")), his
nephew Cammy (Blake Garrett Rosenthal), and his uncle Heinrich ([Tom
Bower](/wiki/Tom_Bower_\(actor\) "Tom Bower \(actor\)")). The family learns
that Aunt Shirley has willed the siblings her estate on the condition that
they all come back home to run it. Despite Dwight's enthusiasm in inheriting
it, Fannie and Jeb are unwilling to move back in due to the lack of
sophistication farm life offers. Nevertheless, Dwight convinces them to help
him run the farm.

Meanwhile, [Todd Packer](/wiki/Todd_Packer "Todd Packer") ([David
Koechner](/wiki/David_Koechner "David Koechner")) visits the office and
announces that he wants to make amends for his past behavior. He makes rude
remarks masked as apologies and hands out store-bought cupcakes. [Pam
Halpert](/wiki/Pam_Beesly "Pam Beesly") ([Jenna Fischer](/wiki/Jenna_Fischer
"Jenna Fischer")) argues that they should not eat the cupcakes, to spite
Packer. She remains adamant on this point even after Packer leaves, but once
Pam goes home the remaining employees eat the cupcakes. Packer reveals to the
documentary crew that he spiked the cupcakes with drugs, supposedly as revenge
for getting him fired (though none of the employees present save Nellie had
anything to do with his being fired). He then visits [Jim
Halpert](/wiki/Jim_Halpert "Jim Halpert") ([John
Krasinski](/wiki/John_Krasinski "John Krasinski")) and [Darryl
Philbin](/wiki/Darryl_Philbin "Darryl Philbin") ([Craig
Robinson](/wiki/Craig_Robinson_\(actor\) "Craig Robinson \(actor\)")) at
Athlead in Philadelphia, pulling the same trick on them. In the morning, Pam
returns to the office and announces she is going to eat her cupcake, only to
find everyone else reeling from the aftereffects of Packer's deed.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Farm_\(The_Office\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Production")]

[![Delfino holding a microphone while
seated](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Majandra_Delfino_at_ATX_2014.jpg/220px-
Majandra_Delfino_at_ATX_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Majandra_Delfino_at_ATX_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Majandra_Delfino_at_ATX_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

[Majandra Delfino](/wiki/Majandra_Delfino "Majandra Delfino") guest starred as
Dwight's sister.

The episode was written and directed by executive producer and former
showrunner [Paul Lieberstein](/wiki/Paul_Lieberstein "Paul Lieberstein"),
marking his thirteenth writing credit, sixth directorial credit and fourth
dual credit.[3] "The Farm" was the fifth episode produced, but was the
seventeenth aired, as noted by its production number.[1] It was originally
supposed to act as a [backdoor pilot](/wiki/Backdoor_pilot "Backdoor pilot")
for a spin-off series starring Wilson and focusing on Dwight. As such, Wilson
was initially slated to appear in only 13 episodes of _The Office_ 's ninth
season before leaving for the spin-off.[4] Paul Lieberstein, the showrunner
for _The Office_ for seasons five through eight, stepped down at the start of
season nine in order to focus more energy on the potential spin-off.[5]
However, upon review, the spin-off was not picked up by NBC.[6] Executive
producer [Greg Daniels](/wiki/Greg_Daniels "Greg Daniels") revealed that the
episode would have additional material shot so that it fits better into the
season, as the original version contained "certain aspects that were
appropriate for a pilot of a new show".[7]

The episode guest stars Majandra Delfino, Blake Garrett Rosenthal, [Thomas
Middleditch](/wiki/Thomas_Middleditch "Thomas Middleditch"), Matt Jones, and
Tom Bower as members of Dwight's family; Delfino plays Dwight's sister Fannie,
Rosenthal plays Dwight's nephew Cammy, Middleditch portrays Dwight's brother
Jeb, Jones portrays Dwight's cousin Zeke, and Bower appears as Dwight's great
uncle Heinrich, in a deleted scene.[2][6][8] Jones had previously appeared in
the ninth season entry, "[Junior Salesman](/wiki/Junior_Salesman "Junior
Salesman")".[9]

## Broadcast and
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Farm_\(The_Office\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Broadcast and reception")]

###
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Farm_\(The_Office\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Ratings")]

"The Farm" originally aired on NBC on March 14, 2013, after a four-week
hiatus.[10] In its original American broadcast, the episode was viewed by an
estimated 3.54 million viewers and received a 1.9 rating/5 percent share.[11]
This means that it was seen by 1.9 percent of all 18- to 49-year-olds, and 5
percent of all 18- to 49-year-olds watching television at the time of the
broadcast. This marked a decrease in the ratings from the previous episode,
"[Moving On](/wiki/Moving_On_\(The_Office\) "Moving On \(The
Office\)")".[11][12] _The Office_ ranked fourth in its timeslot, being beaten
by an episode of the [CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS") police procedural _[Person of
Interest](/wiki/Person_of_Interest_\(TV_series\) "Person of Interest \(TV
series\)")_ which received a 2.9/8 percent rating, an entry of the
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
series _[Grey's Anatomy](/wiki/Grey%27s_Anatomy "Grey's Anatomy")_ which
received a 2.6/7 percent rating, and an installment of the
[Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") series
_[Glee](/wiki/Glee_\(TV_series\) "Glee \(TV series\)")_ which received a 2.0/6
percent rating.[11] Despite this, the episode was the highest-rated NBC series
for the night.[11] 1.90 million viewers watched the episode via DVR playback,
bringing the total viewership to 5.36 million viewers and a 3.0 18–49
rating.[13]

###
Reviews[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Farm_\(The_Office\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Reviews")]

"Then there was the open-endedness of Dwight walking onto the farm with his
brother and sister, the beginning of the new life. The tone didn't match. None
of this was necessarily bad on its own, but because we know what we know, it
came off less like a weird outing for Dwight and revealed the stitching of
people trying to patch in a standalone episode... which by mere approach made
it feel larger and grander, the seams of the monster."

—Nick Campbell, [TV.com](/wiki/TV.com "TV.com")[14]

"The Farm" received mostly negative reviews from critics, many criticizing
Dwight's farm storyline and some critics calling it a "Frankenstein
episode".[14][15] M. Giant of [Television Without
Pity](/wiki/Television_Without_Pity "Television Without Pity") awarded the
episode a C.[16] [Alan Sepinwall](/wiki/Alan_Sepinwall "Alan Sepinwall") of
_[HitFix](/wiki/HitFix "HitFix")_ considered NBC's decision not to pick the
spin-off for more episodes the right decision, writing that the characters and
scenes were "barely sketches" and featured too much "cartoonishness".
Sepinwall also criticized the Todd Packer scenes, and only saw Dwight's
interactions with his nephew, Cammy, in a positive light.[17]
[TV.com](/wiki/TV.com "TV.com") columnist Nick Campbell called the farm
storyline "unnatural" compared to the episode and the series, as a whole, and
wrote that the tone to the ending "didn't match". Despite this, he
complimented the storyline for "establishing tone, characters, and direction
in literally half the time usually allotted".[14] _[The A.V.
Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V. Club")_ reviewer Erik Adams complimented
the episode for serving as a "breather" from the season's long arcs, and gave
good background information into Dwight's personality. He went on to criticize
the pilot's broad humor, writing that following the scene featuring Dwight
shooting a shotgun into his aunt's casket, "it would be next to impossible for
_The Farm_ to heighten from that point". Adams graded the episode a B.[18]

Damon Houx of Screen Crush called the two storylines "two pieces of that
[_[sic](/wiki/Sic "Sic")_] didn't work all that well together", which all
added to a "dull" episode. Houx complimented Koechner's performance, calling
him a "great improviser" but wrote that the whole plot was lacking. He also
considered the farm plotline to be pointless and aimless, especially due to it
airing in the last few episodes of the series.[19]
